overview.short: Pseudomonas putida is a Gram-negative, aerobic, non-fermenting rod commonly found in soil and water and occasionally implicated in opportunistic infections.
overview.clinical_context: Associated with opportunistic infections and device-related infections, particularly in healthcare settings, though less virulent than P. aeruginosa.

species_markers.notes: Typically does not produce pyocyanin; fluorescence may be absent or weak depending on strain.
Helps separate from P. aeruginosa which commonly grows at 42째C.
Often smoother and less spreading/metallic than P. aeruginosa.

common_confusions.reason: Similar non-fermenter profile; differentiation may rely on pigment/fluorescence and confirmatory identification.
Both can be oxidase-positive non-fermenters; definitive identification often requires MALDI-TOF or molecular methods.

when_to_question_identification: Growth at 42째C suggests P. aeruginosa rather than P. putida.
Blue-green pigment (pyocyanin) argues strongly against P. putida.
Oxidase negativity suggests a different non-fermenter genus.

recommended_next_tests.reason: Recommended biochemical panel for non-fermenting Gram-negative rods.
Most reliable confirmation at species level.
Recommended if precise species differentiation is needed within closely related Pseudomonas groups.
